dictionary.phrase: raise havoc with someone or something
dictionary.definition: to create confusion or disruption for or among someone or something.  Your announcement raised havoc with the students.  I didn’t mean to play havoc with them.

dictionary.phrase: play havoc with someone or something

dictionary.phrase: raise hob with someone or something
dictionary.definition: to do something devilish to someone or something; to cause trouble for someone or something. (A hob is a hobgoblin, a wicked little elf.) _ Your sudden arrival is going to play hob with my dinner plans.  Sorry, I didn’t mean to raise hob with you.

dictionary.phrase: raise money for someone or something
dictionary.definition: to work to earn money or encourage donations for the benefit of someone, something, or doing something. I worked hard to raise money for college, and then decided not to go.

Prov. You can tell when something is about to fail because large numbers of people begin to leave it. (Can imply that the people who leave are “rats,” that is, selfish and disloyal.) _ Jill: The company next door must be going bankrupt. Jane: How do you know? Jill: All its employees are resigning. Rats abandon a sinking ship.

dictionary.phrase: reckon someone or something into something

dictionary.phrase: recognize something for what it is
dictionary.definition: to see and understand exactly what someone or something is or represents. The disease represented a serious threat to all peoples, and Dr. Smith recognized it for what it was.  I recognize you for what you are, you scoundrel!

dictionary.phrase: recoil at the sight (of someone or something)
dictionary.definition: to flinch or cringe at the sight or thought of someone or something.  Sally recoiled at the sight of Gerry, who had said something unspeakable.  Mary recoiled at the very thought.

dictionary.phrase: refer something back to someone or something

dictionary.phrase: remand someone (in)to the custody of someone
dictionary.definition: to order someone placed into the custody of someone.  The court remanded the prisoner into the custody of the sheriff. The judge remanded Mary to the custody of the sheriff.  The judge remanded Gerald over to his father.

to order someone placed into the custody of someone.  The court remanded the prisoner into the custody of the sheriff. The judge remanded Mary to the custody of the sheriff.  The judge remanded Gerald over to his father.

a final parting comment made to remind someone going on a journey to write to those remaining at home.  Alice: Bye. Mary: Good-bye, Alice. Remember to write. Alice: I will. Bye.  Sally: Remember to write! Fred: I will!

dictionary.phrase: render something to someone or something
dictionary.definition: to give something to someone or a group.  You must render your taxes to the government.  I will render my money to the tax collector.  I had to render up all my earnings.

dictionary.phrase: render something up (to someone or something)

dictionary.phrase: replace someone or something by someone or something
dictionary.definition: to remove someone or something and add someone or something in place of the first.  The manager replaced two workers by a machine.  Walter replaced his old lawn mower with a newer one.

dictionary.phrase: replace someone or something with someone or something

to reinstate someone’s belief, faith, trust, etc., in something.  I knew that a good performance on the test would restore my parents’ belief in me.  Her faith was restored in the government.

to make one’s good fortune or success on the strength of someone else’s. (Also with else, as in the examples.) _ Bill isn’t very creative, so he rides on John’s coattails.  Some people just have to hang on somebody else’s coattails.

dictionary.phrase: ride roughshod over someone or something
dictionary.definition: to treat someone or something with disdain or scorn.  Tom seems to ride roughshod over his friends.  You shouldn’t have come into our town to ride roughshod over our laws and our traditions.

dictionary.phrase: run roughshod over someone or something

to both sides; on all sides; everywhere.  I dropped the tennis balls, and they rolled right and left.  There were children everywhere— running right and left.

immediately. John: Take this over to Sue. Bill: Right away. John: How soon can you do this? Sue: Right away.

ideally suited to one’s interests or abilities. Skiing is right down my alley. I love it.  This kind of thing is right up John’s alley.

immediately; first thing. When he was learning to ride a bicycle, he fell on his head right off the bat.  The new manager demanded new office furniture right off the bat.

the freedom to do something; the legal or moral permission or license to do something. (*Typically: get ~; have ~; give someone ~.) _ You don’t have the right to enter my home without my permission. I have a right to grow anything I want on my farmland.

1. Fig. to lower a theater curtain, usually at the end of an act or a play. (More literal than W.) _ After one hundred performances, it’s time to ring the curtain down on our show for the last time.  As we bring down the curtain on another successful performance, let’s be thankful nothing serious went wrong. 2. Fig. to bring something to an end; to declare something to be at an end. It’s time to ring the curtain down on our relationship. We have nothing in common anymore.  We’ve tried our best to make this company a success, but it’s time to ring down the curtain.

1. Fig. to lower a theater curtain, usually at the end of an act or a play. (More literal than W.) _ After one hundred performances, it’s time to ring the curtain down on our show for the last time. It’s time to ring the curtain down on our relationship. We have nothing in common anymore.  We’ve tried our best to make this company a success, but it’s time to ring down the curtain.

to punish one by washing one’s mouth out with soap, especially for using foul language. (Usually a jocular threat.) _If you say that again, I’ll rinse your mouth out with soap. I will wash out your mouth if you swear.

dictionary.phrase: rip something out of someone or something

a chance of precipitation. (Used only in weather forecasting. There is no “risk” of hazard or injury involved.) _ And for tomorrow, there is a slight risk of showers in the morning. There is a 50 percent risk of rain tonight.

1. Fig. Inf. to beat or win over, as in a sports contest.  Our team romped on our opponents and beat them 10 to 1.  We romped all over them. 2. Fig. Inf. to scold someone. The teacher romped on the students for their behavior.  He romped all over all of them.

dictionary.phrase: root someone or something out of something

dictionary.phrase: rule in favor of someone or something

to take a chance that something (bad) will happen.  I don’t want to run the risk of losing my job.  Don’t worry. You won’t have to run a risk.

to run a ship or an organization in an orderly and disciplined manner. (Taut and tight mean the same thing. Taut is correct nautical use.) _ The new office manager really runs a tight ship.  Captain Jones is known for running a taut ship.

to run a ship or an organization in an orderly and disciplined manner. (Taut and tight mean the same thing. Taut is correct nautical use.) _ The new office manager really runs a tight ship.  Captain Jones is known for running a taut ship.

to go awry; to go bad; to turn bad; to go into a frenzy. (From a Malay word meaning to run wild in a violent frenzy.) _Our plan ran amok. He ran amuck early in the school year and never quite got back on the track.

to go awry; to go bad; to turn bad; to go into a frenzy. (From a Malay word meaning to run wild in a violent frenzy.) _Our plan ran amok. He ran amuck early in the school year and never quite got back on the track.
to take a short trip to do a specific thing; to complete an errand. I’ve got to run an errand. I’ll be back in a minute.  John has gone on an errand. He’ll be back shortly.
to take a short trip to do a specific thing; to complete an errand. I’ve got to run an errand. I’ll be back in a minute.  John has gone on an errand. He’ll be back shortly.

dictionary.phrase: run around like a chicken with its head cut off
dictionary.definition: to run around frantically and aimlessly; to be in a state of chaos. (Alludes to a chicken that continues to run around aimlessly after its head has been chopped off.) _ I spent all afternoon running around like a chicken with its head cut off.  If you run around in circles, you’ll never get anything done.

to run around frantically and aimlessly; to be in a state of chaos. (Alludes to a chicken that continues to run around aimlessly after its head has been chopped off.) _ I spent all afternoon running around like a chicken with its head cut off.  If you run around in circles, you’ll never get anything done.

to outrun or outdo someone. (Alludes to someone who runs fast enough to run in circles around a competitor and still win the race.) _ John is a much better racer than Mary. He can run circles around her. Mary can run rings around Sally.

to outrun or outdo someone. (Alludes to someone who runs fast enough to run in circles around a competitor and still win the race.) _ John is a much better racer than Mary. He can run circles around her. Mary can run rings around Sally.

dictionary.phrase: run one’s fingers through one’s hair
dictionary.definition: to comb one’s hair with one’s fingers.  I came in out of the wind and ran my fingers through my hair to straighten it out a bit. He ran his hand through his hair and tried to make himself presentable.

dictionary.phrase: run one’s hand through one’s hair
dictionary.definition: to comb one’s hair with one’s fingers.  I came in out of the wind and ran my fingers through my hair to straighten it out a bit. He ran his hand through his hair and tried to make himself presentable.
to get out of control.  The dandelions have run riot in our lawn.  The children ran wild at the birthday party and had to be taken home.
to get out of control.  The dandelions have run riot in our lawn.  The children ran wild at the birthday party and had to be taken home.

dictionary.phrase: run someone or something into something
dictionary.definition: to take or drive someone or something into something or some place.  Let me run you into the city this morning. I need the car today.  Do you want to go to town? I have to run in George and you can come along.

to take or drive someone or something into something or some place.  Let me run you into the city this morning. I need the car today.  Do you want to go to town? I have to run in George and you can come along.

dictionary.phrase: run someone or something out of something
dictionary.definition: to chase someone or something out of something or some place.  The old man ran the kids out of his orchard.  He ran out the kids.
to chase someone or something out of something or some place.  The old man ran the kids out of his orchard.  He ran out the kids.

1. to guide or route something, such as a wire or a pipe, into something or a place.  The worker ran the circuit into each room.  He ran in the circuit as specified. 2. to guide something into something; to drive or steer something into something else.  Bobby ran his bicycle into the wall, bending the front wheel.  Please don’t run your car into the wall!

He ran in the circuit as specified. 2. to guide something into something; to drive or steer something into something else.  Bobby ran his bicycle into the wall, bending the front wheel.  Please don’t run your car into the wall!
to pound or force something into the ground.  Use a heavy mallet to drive the stakes into the ground.  Run this post into the ground and nail this sign to it.
to pound or force something into the ground.  Use a heavy mallet to drive the stakes into the ground.  Run this post into the ground and nail this sign to it.
to drive or steer something out of something or some place.  The cowboys ran the cattle out of the corral.  They ran out the cattle.
to drive or steer something out of something or some place.  The cowboys ran the cattle out of the corral.  They ran out the cattle.

dictionary.phrase: run something over to someone or something
dictionary.definition: to carry something to someone or something.  Would you please run this package over to Mrs. Franklin? _ Do you know where Bill lives? Please run over this package.
to carry something to someone or something.  Would you please run this package over to Mrs. Franklin? _ Do you know where Bill lives? Please run over this package.

Inf. Please repeat what you just said.; Please go over that one more time.  Alice: Do you understand? Sue: No. I really didn’t understand what you said. Run that by me again, if you don’t mind.  John: Put this piece into the longer slot and the remaining piece into the slot on the bottom. Sue: Run that by again. I got lost just after put.  Mary: Keep to the right, past the fork in the road, then turn right at the crossroads. Do you follow? Jane: No. Run it by me again.

a large demand for something.  There was a rush on bottled water during the drought.  During the hot summer, there was a run on air conditioners.

dictionary.phrase: rush someone or something into something
dictionary.definition: to lead or carry someone or something into something or some place hurriedly.  I rushed her into the hospital emergency room, and everything was soon all right.  The nurse rushed in the emergency medical equipment.

to lead or carry someone or something into something or some place hurriedly.  I rushed her into the hospital emergency room, and everything was soon all right.  The nurse rushed in the emergency medical equipment.

dictionary.phrase: rush someone or something out of something
dictionary.definition: to lead or guide someone or something out of something or some place hurriedly.  The ushers rushed everyone out of the church so they could clean the place before the next wedding.  They rushed out another edition of the newspaper that afternoon.

to lead or guide someone or something out of something or some place hurriedly.  The ushers rushed everyone out of the church so they could clean the place before the next wedding.  They rushed out another edition of the newspaper that afternoon.
dismissal from one’s employment. (*Typically: get ~; give someone ~.) _ Poor Tom got the sack today. He’s always late.  I was afraid that Sally was going to get the ax.

to fulfill a requirement, using a particular thing, such as a school or college course.  Can I satisfy the requirements by taking a course in art? _ Will I satisfy the requirement with this course?

to save someone from injury, embarrassment, or punishment.  I saved my skin by getting the job done on time.  Thanks for saving my neck! I would have fallen down the stairs if you hadn’t held my arm.
to save someone from injury, embarrassment, or punishment.  I saved my skin by getting the job done on time.  Thanks for saving my neck! I would have fallen down the stairs if you hadn’t held my arm.

to reserve something—usually money—for some future need.  I’ve saved a little money for a rainy day.  Keep some extra allowance for a rainy day.

dictionary.phrase: put something aside for a rainy day

dictionary.phrase: hold something back for a rainy day

dictionary.phrase: keep something for a rainy day

to say what one must say; to recite what one has planned to say.  Look, just say your piece and get out of here. I said my piece and left.

Inf. a formulaic answer to Says who? _Tom: Says who? Fred: Says me, that’s who! _Tom: You? Fred: You got it, buster. Says me!
Inf. a formulaic answer to Says who? _Tom: Says who? Fred: Says me, that’s who! _Tom: You? Fred: You got it, buster. Says me!

Inf. a formulaic challenge indicating disagreement with someone who has said something.  Tom: Says who? Fred: Says me, that’s who! _ She drew herself up to her full height, looked him straight in the eye, and said, “Says who?”

Cliché scarce; seldom found. (*Also: as ~.) _ I do declare, decent people are as scarce as hen’s teeth in these chaotic times. Handmade lace is scarcer than hen’s teeth; most lace is made by machine.

dictionary.phrase: scare someone or an animal out of something
dictionary.definition: to frighten someone or an animal out of something or some place. The old man tried to scare the kids out of his orchard by shouting at them.  Karen scared out the intruder.

dictionary.phrase: scare someone or an animal out†
dictionary.definition: to frighten someone or an animal out of something or some place. The old man tried to scare the kids out of his orchard by shouting at them.  Karen scared out the intruder.
to throw or distribute something about.  The children scattered the books about and left the room in a general mess.  They scattered about all the books and papers.
to throw or distribute something about.  The children scattered the books about and left the room in a general mess.  They scattered about all the books and papers.
to remove something from something by dipping or scooping.  She scooped the water out of the bottom of the rowboat.  Karen scooped out the water.
to remove something from something by dipping or scooping.  She scooped the water out of the bottom of the rowboat.  Karen scooped out the water.
to clean something off something else by scouring. (Of is usually retained before pronouns.) _See if you can scour the rust off the cookie sheet. I will scour off the rust with steel wool.
to clean something off something else by scouring. (Of is usually retained before pronouns.) _See if you can scour the rust off the cookie sheet. I will scour off the rust with steel wool.
to manage just to get along with a minimum amount of something.  We can just scrape along on the money I earn from my sewing.  Do you think you can scrape along with just $400 per month?
to manage just to get along with a minimum amount of something.  We can just scrape along on the money I earn from my sewing.  Do you think you can scrape along with just $400 per month?

to manage just to get by with something. (Usually applies to a more specific period or time or a more specific event than scrape along (on something).) _ There is not really enough money to live on, and we just have to scrape by on what we can earn.  We can’t scrape by with only that amount of money.

to manage just to get by with something. (Usually applies to a more specific period or time or a more specific event than scrape along (on something).) _ There is not really enough money to live on, and we just have to scrape by on what we can earn.  We can’t scrape by with only that amount of money.

to find and collect something; to locate and assemble a group of people or things. (Based on scrape something up.) _ I’m sure we can scrape up someone for the job.  Mary scraped a few dollars together for some new books.  John barely scraped up enough money to pay his rent.

to find and collect something; to locate and assemble a group of people or things. (Based on scrape something up.) _ I’m sure we can scrape up someone for the job.  Mary scraped a few dollars together for some new books.  John barely scraped up enough money to pay his rent.

dictionary.phrase: scrape something off (of) someone or something
dictionary.definition: to rub or stroke something off someone or something. (Of is usually retained before pronouns.) _I sat down and scraped the caked mud off of me. It was everywhere! _ Jake scraped off the rust.
to rub or stroke something off someone or something. (Of is usually retained before pronouns.) _I sat down and scraped the caked mud off of me. It was everywhere! _ Jake scraped off the rust.
to remove something by scraping.  Scrape all the peanut butter out of the jar before you discard it.  Scrape out the peanut butter.
to remove something by scraping.  Scrape all the peanut butter out of the jar before you discard it.  Scrape out the peanut butter.
to hunt for something in dirt, gravel, rocks, etc. The prospector spent the day scratching about for signs of gold. The chickens were scratching around for something to eat.
to hunt for something in dirt, gravel, rocks, etc. The prospector spent the day scratching about for signs of gold. The chickens were scratching around for something to eat.
to complain bitterly; to complain unduly. When we put him in an office without a window, he screamed bloody murder.  There is something wrong next door. Everyone is yelling bloody murder.
to complain bitterly; to complain unduly. When we put him in an office without a window, he screamed bloody murder.  There is something wrong next door. Everyone is yelling bloody murder.

dictionary.phrase: screen someone or something out of something
dictionary.definition: to filter someone or something out of something.  The test screened all the unqualified candidates out of the group.  We screened out the suppliers who were not financially sound.
to filter someone or something out of something.  The test screened all the unqualified candidates out of the group.  We screened out the suppliers who were not financially sound.

to be very thrifty; to live on very little money, often in order to save up for something.  We had to scrimp and save in order to send the children to college.  The Smiths pinched and scraped all year in order to go on a Caribbean cruise.

to clean something off something by scrubbing. (Of is usually retained before pronouns.) _I have to scrub the mud off the porch steps.  Did you scrub off all the grease?

to clean something out of something by scrubbing.  Please scrub the gravy out of the pot.  Are you going to scrub out the burned material?

to signify or celebrate the reaching of an agreement or bargain. They signed the papers and sealed the bargain by drinking champagne.

dictionary.phrase: seal something off from someone or something
dictionary.definition: to make something inaccessible to someone or something. The police sealed the building off from everyone. They sealed off the building from all the reporters.
to make something inaccessible to someone or something. The police sealed the building off from everyone. They sealed off the building from all the reporters.
written and sent with love and care. (The initialism is sometimes written on love letters. Also an acronym.) _ All her letters come SWAK.  I know they are sealed with a kiss, because she says so.
